awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The evolution of gene regulatory networks for regeneration
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical paragraph:
Regeneration is a fascinating phenomenon whereby an adult animal makes new cells and structures in response to injury.  This project focuses on understanding, at the cellular level, how the earliest responses upon injury lead to correct regeneration of missing tissues. How does the animal know that it has lost organs and how does it make the right cells in the right places? Although many animal species can regenerate, the details of the underlying molecular pathways and how these pathways compare across species remain unknown. Biological pathways acquire changes in all species over the course of many generations, but evolution tends to preserve pathways that are essential. Therefore, by studying two species of distantly-related worms that both have impressive regeneration abilities, this project will reveal which aspects of regeneration are shared, and hence essential. The general principles of regeneration identified through this work will have relevance to regenerative medicine. In addition to the training of students and postdoctoral researchers involved in this research, the broader impacts of this project include providing hands-on experiences with molecular studies of evolutionary biology to students at local public schools. Teachers will receive training, equipment, supplies, and staff support to implement curriculum that incorporates experimental molecular biology. Direct experiences with how science is practiced in research labs will enhance retention of students in STEM fields. 

Technical paragraph:
Many extant lineages of animals can regenerate any missing cell type, raising the possibility that the earliest animals to evolve were capable of "whole-body" regeneration. Functional studies of multiple species in phylogenetically informative positions relative to each other are needed to evaluate how the gene regulatory networks (GRNs) underlying regeneration have evolved. This research will leverage the planarian Schmidtea mediterranea and the acoel Hofstenia miamia; both regenerate all missing tissues, are easy to culture, and offer high-throughput screening of gene function via RNAi.  Importantly, Hofstenia offers an additional advantage: the availability of accessible embryos, which will enable functional studies of regulatory DNA proposed here. Acoels represent the earliest lineage of animals with bilateral symmetry (Bilateria), and therefore, comparisons of acoels and planarians will reveal the evolution of GRNs over 550 million years of evolution. Wnt signaling, which has a conserved role in correctly specifying tissue identity along the anterior-posterior axis in Hofstenia and Schmidtea, will serve as an anchor-point for a systems-level approach to identify upstream and downstream GRNs. Wound-induced gene networks that control the Wnt pathway will be identified by transcriptome profiling and RNAi. Assays for open chromatin will be used to identify enhancers and direct transcriptional regulators of Wnt pathway components. RNAseq and candidate gene approaches will be used to identify downstream gene networks controlled by Wnt signaling. Together, these experiments will reveal the regulatory mechanisms through which wound-induced gene networks control a putatively conserved module for patterning new tissue in two animal phyla.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectural Merit

Most animals are able to repair wounds, but many are capable of regeneration, a process of replacing tissue that was lost to injury. Some animals can regrow certain organs or structures, for example humans can regenerate their liver and salamanders can regenerate their limbs. Other animals are able to regenerate even more impressively, where they are able to make any cell type or tissue and can restore whole new animals from small fragments. This process is referred to as whole-body regeneration (WBR), and it is widespread across the animal tree of life. In this project, we asked whether any unifying principles underlie WBR.

            To be able to identify unifying principles, we need a framework for comparing how regeneration works across distantly-related animals. We therefore sought to develop an approach to build gene regulatory networks (GRNs) for regeneration, as GRNs have been used in the field of evolutionary developmental biology to make effective comparisons of biological processes. We utilized a new research organism, the three-banded panther worm Hofstenia miamia because shows robust WBR and we have established many tools to study genetic pathways in this species. Additionally, Hofstenia is an acoel, a group of marine worms that are distantly-related to other animals where scientists are studying WBR, and this phylogenetic position gives Hofstenia a valuable comparative vantage point.

            We generated chromatin profiling data, which reveal which regions of DNA in the genome that are active and could be playing an important role, from regenerating Hofstenia. We combined these data with studies of gene function using RNA interference, which allowed us to connect transcription factor genes to the target genes that they control during regeneration, building the first gene regulatory network for whole-body regeneration. Briefly, we found that a gene named egr becomes expressed within 30 minutes to an hour of cutting the animal, consistent with its known role in other animals as an “immediate early gene”. We found that egr acts as a major regulatory factor that activates other regeneration genes, including two genes of the Wnt pathway. Now that we have developed a method for identifying the mechanism of how Wnt pathway genes are controlled in regeneration in Hofstenia, this approach can be applied to other systems. Wnt pathway genes are also known to be important for regeneration in other animals, such as planarian flatworms and cnidarians. Recent data from these other species suggest that our finding that an immediate early gene controls Wnt pathway gene expression could be an emerging unifying principle of regeneration biology.

            As part of this project, we also identified the NFY complex as a key regulator of neural regeneration and studied the roles of the non-canonical Wnt/Planar Cell Polarity genes in Hofstenia regeneration. Together, this work can serve as the basis of many new explorations of regeneration, such as understanding which pathways are responsible for the activation of immediate early genes and which lie further downstream in Hofstenia and in other species, and further comparing these mechanisms to understand the evolution of regeneration.

 

Broader Impacts

The approach we developed for building gene regulatory networks for regeneration can be applied to other species and we helped others learn our method for obtaining chromatin profiling data by presenting a webinar and publishing a methods paper. We uploaded all our sequence data to public databases where it is freely available for others to use. We engaged with the public in a discussion about the impact of our work via an “Ask me anything” session on Reddit. We also worked with middle school teachers and students by hosting a workshop for teachers to gain hands-on experience with the study of evolutionary biology. Teachers extracted DNA from different foods from a grocery store, ranging from spinach to turkey, obtained the sequence of a gene found in all species, and used bioinformatic tools to build evolutionary trees to understand the relationships of these organisms. We then supported the teachers in bringing this curriculum to their classrooms, where students appreciated getting to meet real scientists and working with scientific equipment like pipets and gel electrophoresis apparatuses. Overall, our work enabled us to have impact on many communities, ranging from scientists in our discipline to middle school teachers and learners to the general public.
